commitMessage:
OS-6869 sync bhyve with upstream
Reviewed by: Mike Gerdts <mike.gerdts@joyent.com>
Reviewed by: John Levon <john.levon@joyent.com>
Approved by: John Levon <john.levon@joyent.com>

comments.message: Uploaded patch set 1.

Patch Set 1:

This wad consists mostly of update diffs taken directly from upstream.  The pieces which require the closes scrutiny are vmx_support.s (where we've chosen bespoke logic for the VMX entry/exit handling) and vmm_sol_dev.c (our custom driver glue).

Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)

Patch Set 1:

I've looked but have nothing to add to what John found.

Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)

Uploaded patch set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased.
Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1
Uploaded patch set 6: Patch Set 5 was rebased.

Patch Set 6:

I smoke-tested this with Linux an OmniOS guests.  There didn't appear to be any obvious regressions.
Patch Set 6: Integration-Approval+1
Uploaded patch set 7: Commit message was updated.
Change has been successfully merged by Patrick Mooney
Maybe this routine should be added to kaif_toxic_text()?
I'm inclined to avoid the belt-and-suspenders on this one since the explicit flag-twiddling is already here from upstream.  Ideally, no one has reason to go single-stepping through this mess anyways.
As the comment makes clear, the twiddling is insufficient. But I don't feel strongly.

I think if we're going to add that protection, we would want to constrain the scope of it as much as possible.  That would likely mean moving the DR logic into our vmx_enter_guest(), so it was only the one function body which isn't single-step-able.
count cannot be zero.
Couldn't it be, from a malicious caller?  I'm happy to be a stickler here.
Even a malicious caller isn't getting a negative value into an unsigned int :) Would prefer a correct comparison here - if nothing else, I'm surprised the compiler isn't complaining at you.
Well, it's to guard against that definition being changed later, but I don't care deeply about it.  Will switch to the simple zero comparison.
While it seems OK right now, paranoia would suggest that we validate regnums[i] is >= 0.
That sounds good.  I'm not sure why it's not part of vm_[gs]et_register, but that can be something we fix up later (in upstream).
Agreed it would be much nicer in the callee, for later.
